passages.text: Rating Change: BUY | PO: 10,500 EUR | Price: 8,010 EUR

We upgrade Lotus Bakeries (LOTB) to a Buy rating (from Neutral), with an APV- driven PO of EUR10,500 (32% upside) and add it to the SMID cap Europe Best Ideas list. Performance YTD (- 27%) has been driven primarily by compressing multiples (Exhibit 5), in our view, linked to a growth slowdown in FY25 with Biscoff capacity constraints. We believe 1H26 should be the turning point for growth momentum (Exhibit 1) with a sequential pick- up after the Biscoff Thailand plant starts production (which we expect will boost supply by +16%) while brand equity continues to improve (Exhibit 12). Additionally, partnerships with Mondelez (Europe Chocolate, India Biscuits) and Froneri (Europe Ice Cream then global roll out) will kick- in fully in 2026. Meanwhile, Natural Food International (Nakd, Trek, BEAR) continues its global expansion underpinned by the strong >30% OG in 1H25.

While topline momentum is key for sentiment, we also see upside to an already strong EBIT margin (FY24 = 16.8%) and ROIC (17.6%). We expect margins to increase to ca. 18% by FY28E (Exhibit 3; well ahead of cons. at 16.4%), supported by COGS deflation and operating leverage (+150bps), the Thailand factory opening (benefitting labour and transportation costs), local spread production in FY26 and partnerships (accretive phaseout of Ice Cream and Chocolate). However, we see a partial offset higher A&P and D&A spend (from capex plans) to fuel growth. This, combined with ca. 10% OG, will underpin a solid 13.6% EPS CAGR FY25- 28E (vs European Staples at ca. 8%).

We see LOTB as a quality growth compounder, supported by capacity expansion capex (with plans for FY26 already communicated to avoid another supply- gap year). The recent derating (FY26 33x P/E; 5% discount to Lindt & Sprungli) provides an attractive entry point ahead of a clear 2026 acceleration. Additionally, limited exposure to cocoa (ca. 5% of COGS) allows Lotus to benefit from consumer trading out of chocolate confectionery to other snacking categories without cannibalization, especially in the US. We notch down EPS by - 1% pa for FY25- 26E, as we incorporate latest actuals, update for FX, and adjust margin forecasts- We are O/6/9% above consensus on FY25- 28 EPS.

Company DescriptionLotus is a European confectionery pure play with total sales of ca. €1.2bn in 2024, split across 1) Lotus Biscoff (49% of sales), focused on spekulous and adjacencies, 2) Lotus Natural Food (21%), targeting healthy snacking, with key brands being BEAR, Nakd, Kiddylicious and Trek, 3) Local Heroes (19%), which produces Cake, Waffles and Gingerbread, with local brands such as Dinosaurus, Peijnenburg and Snelle Jelle, Annas, etc., 4) Private Label manufacturing (13%) of spekulous for third parties.

Investment RationaleOur Buy rating on Lotus is based on: 1) Biscoff and Natural Foods now represent ca. 70% of revenue and should drive growth through geographic roll-out, penetration increase and SKU launches. 2) Operating leverage and COGS deflation should allow the company to continue expand margin while reinvesting in commercial overhead and A&P to drive topline growth, and 3) Thailand Biscoff factory opening early 2026 will fix supply limitation and inflect topline & EPS momentum.

1H25 growth was solid for Lotus Bakeries at \(+9.7\%\) YoY, especially in light of a disappointing reporting season for Staples with a weakening of the global consumer. However, this growth needs to be put into context, as some of it was a carryover from 2H24. Indeed, 2H24 grew at \(12.6\%\) with \(6.7\%\) carryover and \(5.9\%\) sequential growth, which directly fed into the 1H25 number. As such, 1H25 growth was split between \(5.6\%\) carryover and \(4.1\%\) sequential growth, in our view. The slowdown here was partly due to supply constraints at Biscoff. This implies that carryover growth for 2H25 will be lower at \(3.9\%\) , and further improvement would need to be sequential. We firmly believe that 2H25 should mark the lowest point of growth for Lotus, especially as supply limitations will meet the progressive phase- out of Biscoff Ice Cream and Chocolate to make way for the Mondelez and Froneri partnerships.

Nonetheless, the most important news in 1H25 results. in our view, was the confirmation that the Biscoff Thailand factory will progressively ramp up production throughout 1H26 with normalized output reached by May 2026. This should pave the way for at least a \(16\%\) Biscoff supply increase in our view (we will come back to this later), which should underpin a sales volume growth inflection at Biscoff considering brand equity and sell- out have remained strong.
Exhibit 7: After good momentum in FY22- 24, growth decelerated in FY25 and is now set to reaccelerate in FY26.
Lotus Bakeries group growth split across carryover and sequential growth, \(\%\) , Half Years, 2022- 2026E.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

2H25 should be solid for Lotus Natural Foods due to the strong carryover from 1H25's sequential growth. Additionally, with the US putting tariffs on South Africa (30%), we expect this division will need to push up prices as its production is located there. To protect profit while maintaining price competitiveness, we would expect Natural Foods in the US to reach ca. \(10\%\) pricing, which considering its weight in the division should equate ca. \(2\%\) incremental pricing for the Natural Food division.

The Biscoff volume growth slowdown in 2025 was a result of supply limitations (partly due to lower capex in 2023, in our view). This by nature is temporary and will be fixed in 2026 when the new production lines in Thailand and more globally start ramping up. As such, for us it is more important to track Biscoff momentum and awareness, and we show in Exhibit 10 and Exhibit 12 the Google searches for Biscoff in the US and globally (with record searches being indexed at 100). Growth in the number of searches is very healthy based on a 12- week moving average, with recent trends of \(35\%\) in the US (Exhibit 11) and above \(30\%\) globally (Exhibit 13).

Overall, Lotus's performance in tracked channels has remained good year to date in the US, confirming the expansion story there continues apace in both Healthy Snacks and Biscoff. More importantly, the fading pricing tailwind has been replaced by very healthy volume growth, which implies higher- quality organic growth all round. Elevated inflation in cocoa and category weakness in the US likely imply that Lotus is benefitting from some trading out of chocolate confectionery towards Healthier Snacks and Cookies, which bodes well for performance in the coming months and 2026. In the 4W ending 12/07, Lotus Bakeries' performance was \(+26\%\) value growth, with Biscoff at \(+13\%\) and Bear at \(+47\%\)

A note on how we track NielsenIQ data for Lotus Bakeries: Nielsen data is focused on retail sales and does not capture online traffic, D2C sales, Specialized channels (Specialty stores, OOH), or big box stores (i.e. Costco and peers). We estimate that NielsenIQ tracked channels capture broadly \(65\%\) of Lotus US sales, considering the importance of online, airline sales and big box stores for Lotus.

Cash generation has been very volatile historically, reflecting the size of Lotus's capital expenditure plans. But we view this as a positive sign for growth as today's capex is indicative of tomorrow's volume supply (and growth). We believe the market is currently very positive on additional capex programs as topline growth remains a key focus for investors, especially when combined with Lotus's high ROIC (FY24 = 17.6%). At 1H24 results, the company increased its FY24- 25 capex plan from EUR200m to EUR275m and in 1H25 it announced that the FY25- 26 program would be around EUR250m, implying more than EUR110m for FY26 with plans to increase Biscoff production, notably in spreads.

BEAR Fruit Snacks organic- volume- price growth split, in USD, YoY change. Retail sales tracked channels, 4 weeks data, 2021- 2025. After strong triple digits growth in 2021- 2022, Bear growth has come down over 2023- 2024 and is now reporting solid consistent growth trends around 50%.
Source: NielsenIQ, BofA Global Research

Source: NielsenIQ, BofA Global Research

In Exhibit 18, we show the current manufacturing footprint for Lotus Bakeries. Plants have so far been centred on Europe, and only been built outside the region (the US and South Africa) since 2019. Additionally, in the Natural Foods division, production is largely done through co-manufacturing. So far only BEAR and Nakd (both globally ex-UK) are manufactured at Lotus's own facilities. The latest plant is the second South Africa one in Wolseley, which is focused on Nakd and started production in February 2024.
Ongoing capex programs focus on increasing Biscoff supply in Asia through the build-up of the Chonburi Biscoff factory, and on expanding production across all three sites.
**Exhibit 18: Current manufacturing footprint centred on Europe**

To assess the potential volume uplift from the Thailand Biscoff plant, we first look at sales in the APAC region (Exhibit 20): about 1.9bn biscuits equivalent in 2025 compared to ca. 12bn at group level. In our view, the minimum volume targeted by Lotus should be equivalent to current sales, i.e. 1.9bn units, or a 16% supply increase for Biscoff in FY26. Additionally, the capex program in FY25-26 to make the three key factories self-sufficient in spread production should push Biscoff volume capabilities across all 3 regions. Another way to think about it, is that, in our understanding, the Chonburi factory should start with four production lines (compared to five in the US and ca. 20 in Belgium). Considering that with five production lines, the US sells the equivalent of 2.4bn cookies, the rough assumption that each line should be able to produce 400-500m cookies looks reasonable and confirms our view that Thailand could boost production by 16% in 2026-27.

Biscoff biscuits volume split across key regions. We define Rest of the World as Latin America and Africa. Data for 2008,2020,2022 and 2025 (equal to 1H25 and 2H24). Americas and APAC relative importance has grew over time except in 2025.

Interestingly, if we look at the volume growth profile of Lotus Biscoff before and after the US Mebane plant production start (normalized production in 2020, opening in August 2019), we can see a clear volume acceleration (Exhibit 21) in CAGR trends, especially in 2020- 22 (although Covid could also have been a benefit). This makes sense to us as safe local supply allows for more aggressive commercial and A&P spend. Further, once capex plans end, a company wants payback on its investment. We would expect similar trends once the Thailand plant opens. Additionally, the current volume that goes to Asia (which is produced in Belgium) would then be freed up, and should allow Lotus to further focus its development in Europe and in the Middle East.
Lotus Biscoff biscuits volume growth across key regions, 2008- 2025. All regions have seen good volume growth upswings despite higher pricing (broadbase inflation) in 2022- 2025.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research

What to expect in future capex programs2023 marked the end of the first cycle of capex centred on building additional production lines at existing manufacturing sites (Lembeke, Mebane, South Africa, Courcelles). The next step since 2024 has been to ramp up Asia production with the Chonburi Biscoff plant. In our view, one of Lotus's key issues was the limited capex in 2023, which led to the ongoing supply constraints in 2025, especially as new factories like Chonburi take 2- 3 years to be fully built up.

One good piece of news from 1H25 results was the confirmation of continued capex investment post 2025 (which will mark the finalization of Chonburi). The new investment for FY26 (at least EUR110mn) implies further capacity build up across the different key plants, notably in Biscoff spreads, with the focus on having production in Mebane (US) and Chonburi (Thailand), instead of importing from Belgium. A move that makes a lot of sense considering tariffs in the US, for instance.

As such, we are not surprised by the continued high capex at Lotus Bakeries in the coming years. And we welcome it as today's capex is tomorrow's supply and thus tomorrow's revenue growth, which, of course, is the key metric underpinning Lotus Bakeries' multiple. Additionally, it provides confidence that Lotus will avoid another supply gap in the coming years as we have seen in 2025.

Exhibit 22: We expect expansion capex to remain elevated in the coming yearsLotus Bakeries split between maintenance and expansion capex, EUR m, 2019- 2026E, both maintenance and expansion capex have been going up over time.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates

Beyond 2026, we expect capex to stay elevated (Exhibit 23) as Biscoff capacity increases (in Thailand and the US especially, as Belgium's freed- up capacity will give respite to Europe and Middle East) and Natural Foods rolls out internationally (South Africa). Neither would we be surprised by: 1) more in- house manufacturing in Natural Foods, either through co- manufacturer repurchases (such as the South Africa plant) or built from scratch; or 2) another Biscoff plant in Latin America as it remains a key untapped confectionery market in terms of sales and manufacturing coverage, especially considering its scale. We also note the benefit of local manufacturing in light of the region's FX volatility.
Lotus Bakeries capital expenditure, 2010- 30E, EUR m. Capex is going up over time to fund supply increase. M&A has been sporadic with the largest one in 2016 with Natural Foods acquisition.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates

Lotus Bakeries has the means to keep investingLotus Bakeries had relatively low leverage in 2024 at around 0.8x, and we expect that ratio to decline, which would free up additional capital that could be allocated accordingly. In our view, shareholder returns remain secondary in the capital allocation policy. We expect the key focus to be organic investments through capex programs, supplemented by bolt-on acquisitions, especially in Lotus Natural Foods to expand the portfolio in adjacent categories, considering the fragmented market and potential for shelf expansion through Lotus's leadership. Also, keep in mind Lotus's corporate venture fund Fast Forward 2032 (FF2032), which invests in Food start-ups, with the optionality to buy the start-up once it has shown proof of concept, such as Peter's Yard in 2022.

If we consider that leverage could go up to \(2x\) ND/EBITDA, it would imply that the company has EUR335m available financing in FY25 already, with this number increasing as the company continues to grow and deleverage.

Lotus Bakeries net debt / EBITDA, in EUR m, 2020- 2030E, Leverage has remained around \(1x\) ND/EBITDA in FY20- 24, and we expect improving FCF to help deleverage further in the coming years for Lotus to become net cash.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates

We believe capex remains the preferred means of capital allocation for shareholders as long as ROIC and ROCE stay high as it is more likely to create value than inorganic investments or shareholder returns.

In the short term we see margins improving (ca. 70bps over the next two years) based on: 1) operating leverage from volume growth, productivity gains and reduced raw material costs; 2) lower labour costs from emerging market production (South Africa and Thailand); 3) reduced transportation costs (especially in FY26) as Thailand ramps up; and 4) the phase- out of co- manufactured ice cream and chocolate (being replaced by direct ingredient sales to Mondelez and Froneri, which will be margin accretive).

Nonetheless, we also see some margin headwinds from US tariffs, rising A&P reinvestment to drive topline growth and higher D&A as the previous (and future) capex programs progressively increase depreciation.

Exhibit 28: We expect limited margin improvement for 2025 as Lotus will increase A&P to fuel topline growth, while transport costs and D&A increase Lotus Bakeries margin bridge for FY25E and FY26E, BofA forecasts per cost centre.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates

Exhibit 29: Medium term, we expect some margin expansion from operating leverage and employee cost growing slower than toplineLotus Bakeries margin bridge for FY24 to FY28E, BofA forecasts per cost centre.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates

Raw materials, packaging and co- manufacturing are the largest part of costs at \(34\%\) in 2024. However, we consider Lotus Bakeries to be better positioned in the coming 12 months than key confectionery peers. It will be one of the few players to benefit from COGS deflation as its raw material prices normalize while many of its listed competitors face continued inflation from still elevated and volatile cocoa prices. We therefore consider Lotus a defensive stock, set to benefit from snacking and confectionery trends and improving margins. Beyond COGS stabilization, we believe co- manufacturing costs should come down, especially as Biscoff ice cream and chocolate are phased out in the next 12 months (ca. EUR30mn of sales) and replaced by ingredient sales to Froneri and Mondelez, which will generate better margins. Combined with operating leverage from continued volume growth, raw materials, packaging and co- manufacturing costs should fall from \(34.1\%\) in FY24 to \(32.7\%\) in 2027E. Moreover, the scaling of partnerships in ice cream and chocolate should create a halo effect on the cookies and spreads part of Biscoff's business.

Lotus Bakeries' key raw materials are wheat flour, sugar and palm oil, and we look at folding box board and testliner for packaging. We also assume that Lotus hedges on average by six months (but up to a year for some raw materials), and carries out a lot of local sourcing, especially for a commodity such as wheat flour where dynamics differ by region. Overall, most of its commodity prices are normalizing.

Palm oil prices (EUR/T) in light blue, price with 6M lag (EUR/T) in dark blue and 6M average in redline, 2019- 2025. After a strong increase over 2019- 2022 from EUR 500/t to 1,700EUR/t, palm oil prices have been going done and are now around EUR 800/t.
Source: Bloomberg, BofA Global Research

As seen in Exhibit 34, cocoa prices have gone up exponentially on unbalanced supply/demand driven by weather conditions and spreading swollen shoot disease in cacao trees in western African countries. We would expect this situation to benefit Lotus, which is not exposed to cocoa, while its peers will need to increase prices.

Cocoa prices (EUR/MT) in light blue, price with 6M lag (EUR/MT) in dark blue and 6M average in redline. 2019- 2025. After a strong increase over 2019- 2025 from EUR 2,000/t to 11,000EUR/t, cocoa prices have been going done and are now around EUR 7,000/t.
Source: Bloomberg, BofA Global Research

The progressive phase- out of Biscoff Chocolate and Ice Cream (EUR30mn of sales), and subsequent replacement by ingredient sales to Mondelez and Froneri, will improve margins (while being a headwind to the topline for the next 12 months). Indeed, sales from co- manufacturing with limited scale (and low priority for Lotus Bakeries as they are not strategic and more of a marketing tool) had, in our view, very low margins (we use \(8\%\) adj. EBIT margins). And these will in turn be replaced by pure ingredient sales (Biscoff crumbs), which come from internal production and have very efficient yields. We therefore expect ingredients margins to be closer to \(15\%\) . We estimate the replacement should result in a 20bps (Exhibit 37) mechanical benefit for Lotus Bakeries over the next 12 months.

Additionally, as seen in Exhibit 35, the outlook for Biscoff Chocolate and Ice Cream was poor considering their non- strategic nature. While the potential in Chocolate is harder to gauge (as it has a smaller initial scale in Biscoff operations, and will be SKU based for Mondelez brands Milka, Cote D'Or and Cadbury), we believe Ice Cream has very strong potential. Froneri in Western Europe has been building the Mondelez brands licence very successfully, with Oreo and Cadbury showing very strong growth (Exhibit 36). Considering Biscoff's brand equity, we believe a similar result should be expected, with the opportunity to bring in a EUR50- 100mn franchise over the next decade, which will offer further ingredient sales for Biscoff (on top of the marketing benefit for its core products).

The launch of Biscoff in India with the licensing to Mondelez, should be another layer of margin improvement for Lotus Bakeries over the coming years. While the specific financials of the deal have not been disclosed, royalties in Consumer are generally around 10- 15% of revenue. On top, LOTB is supplying some specific raw materials to Mondelez, which could add some revenue as well. Considering the limited associated costs, royalties generally come in at \(>90\%\) gross margin in most cases, and we expect a similar framework to apply to Lotus Bakeries. Mondelez has been building a strong platform in India over the past decade. It is using its dominance in the Chocolate Confectionery market (ca. 58% share in India, Exhibit 38) to build its Biscuits franchise (with Oreo spearheading the efforts). Currently, retail value for Oreo are close to EUR200mn. With the right support and by using its strong channel presence, we believe Mondelez can build a EUR retail value business of close to EUR50- 100mn in the next decade, which could bring close to EUR5- 8mn of incremental EBIT for Lotus Bakeries.

In our view, an important part of the margin improvement story will come from personnel costs (as a percentage of sales). In Exhibit 42, we look at the composition and location of Lotus's workforce. 2019 marked a turning point as Lotus opened its first factories outside Europe, with one in the US and one in South Africa, in line with its strategy of localizing production to improve its supply chain. Since then, another plant has been opened in South Africa and one is currently being built in Thailand. As the number of employees in these regions increases, overall cost per employee (Exhibit 43) falls as personnel expenses are much lower than the group average.

We expect that by 2028E, 42% of employees will be in Belgium, 24% in South Africa, 10% in Thailand and 7% in the United States. Overall, we would expect a higher degree of automation in the plants with higher labour costs (i.e. the US, Belgium) vs those in lower-cost countries (South Africa, Thailand), directly benefiting the personnel cost structure.

Lotus total employee costs in absolute terms and as % of group sales, 2018- 2028E. Labour absolute cost have been going up steadily since 2018, but it has come down from 20% to 19% of sales in the meantime by 2025. And we expect further decline toward 18% of sales.
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates

Additionally, labour inflation in both Europe (Exhibit 44) and the US (Exhibit 45) is stabilizing (in euro terms). However, we would also point out that in Belgium, salaries are directly indexed to inflation, which created a strong jump in 2023 and 2024, with much less impact so far in 2025. In other European countries the impact of wage inflation has been less pronounced in 2025, too. Additionally, the USD has come down vs the euro, providing some benefit in terms of US wage inflation in 2025.

In our view, Lotus will focus more resources on its commercial backbone (both A&P and commercial overheads) going forward as this is clearly the easiest way to drive up sales. In Exhibit 47, we can see that Lotus under- invested during Covid (especially as transport costs increased massively in 2021- 22), because of supply constraints. We would expect the company to progressively step up its commercial investment as its supply increases, and we see this P&L structure as healthier (i.e. gross margin improvements partially reinvested in SG&A) and locking in growth.

Additionally, we estimate transport costs represent about \(20\%\) of services & other goods costs, which implies about \(5.5\%\) of group sales. From FY26, there will be less need to transport goods from Belgium to Asia with the production of Biscoff in Thailand, which should improve margin trends and offset the increased A&P reinvestment in the coming years.

For a growth story like Lotus, scaling up supply is key, and the greenfield investments for its own manufacturing footprint from the different capex programs imply that D&A will increase. In Exhibit 48, we show capex vs D&A as a percentage of sales, and we expect the two to progressively converge. However, we see those investments as very positive as they will drive growth in the coming years.

The weak share price performance YTD \((- 25\%)\) has been driven mainly by multiples derating, which, in our view, is a reflection of topline (and EPS growth) deceleration in 2025 as Biscoff supply has been constrained (as we expected in our downgrade from September 2024: Lotus Bakeries NV: Time to digest - downgrade to Neutral 16 September 2024). Nonetheless, 1H25 results were solid and have not resulted in EPS cuts since the beginning of the year. As such, the derating was mainly driven by sentiment, which will believe will improve throughout 2H25 as we get closer to the completion of the Thailand factory, which will solve Biscoff's supply limitations. While 2H25 results should be the lowest point for growth, they are not out until February 2026. By that time, we believe investors will instead be focusing on the solid set- up for Lotus Bakeries in 2026, which should lead to topline (and EPS) growth acceleration, and subsequent multiples rerating.

We believe the FY26 acceleration in both topline and margin improvement will also accelerate EPS growth, which should correlate with multiples rerating. Additionally, when compared with Lindt & Sprungli (LOTB's closest peer in our view, as it is also a pure play, with a similar growth profile and high ROCE), LOTB is now trading at a 5% discount, despite the ongoing cocoa inflation. That implies that Lindt & Sprungli's growth is price-driven, while Lotus's is volume-driven (i.e. higher quality), which deserves a comparative premium, in our view.

Lotus's valuation (FY25- 26E P/E at 39- 34x and EV/sales at 5.6- 5.2x) has been coming down with growth decelerating in the face of supply limitations and high comps. We believe FY26 should pave the way for multiples to rerate considering the solid volume growth algorithm, which is rare among European Staples. EPS growth for Lotus is mainly a function of topline progression (as adj. EBIT margins are already comparable to peers' at 16.8%), which is now primarily volume growth- based as pricing carryover is fading.

While we see limited growth potential in 2H25, we expect momentum to clearly accelerate in 2026. In our view, this will allow for further earnings upgrades or multiples rerating. Lotus Bakeries in an attractive set- up vs other confectionery player as it is unaffected by current cocoa price and supply issues, and even benefits from them (its products with a low price point benefit from end- consumer trading out of chocolate confectionery towards biscuits and other snacks).

Our price objective (PO) for Lotus Bakeries NV shares is EUR 10,500 and is based on the adjusted present value (APV) methodology (a variation of discounted cash flow) whereby we discount the business' operating cash flows at the cost of equity (for Lotus Bakeries, we use \(6.9\%\) ) and the tax shield at the cost of debt \((2\%)\) . We assume a terminal growth rate of \(4\%\) .

Downside risks to PO: slowdown of organic growth, increased competition from emerging challengers/global peers/private label players, change of consumer trends, raw materials inflation, changing macro trends, reduction of calorific intake from GLP- 1 development, higher bond yields, mis- execution on capex program.

Upside risks to PO: stronger-than- expected macroeconomic trends, increase of consumer confidence, higher- than- expected margins/organic growth, raw materials deflation, additional capex programs to increase supply, decrease in bond yields, M&A bolt- on acquisitions.
